block.p: War Financing Approved; Costliest Emergency Bill The Senate gave its final approval to President Bush's request for $87.5 billion to occupy and rebuild Iraq and Afghanistan, completing Congressional action on the largest emergency spending bill ever sought by a president.

War Financing Approved; Costliest Emergency Bill The Senate gave its final approval to President Bush's request for $87.5 billion to occupy and rebuild Iraq and Afghanistan, completing Congressional action on the largest emergency spending bill ever sought by a president.

Loathing for the American occupiers of Iraq looms everywhere in Falluja, where the recent downing of an American helicopter just outside town, killing 16 soldiers and wounding 20 others, prompted celebrations from many of the locals.
A new draft constitution for Afghanistan was unveiled and formally presented to the former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah. The draft will go to a 500-member grand assembly for a vote in December.

Mideast Talks Quietly Resume Senior Israeli and Palestinian leaders have quietly resumed behind-the-scenes discussions in an effort to revive the stalled Middle East peace plan. Meanwhile, in the West Bank, a 16-year-old Palestinian bomber blew himself up, wounding one soldier.

Iranian Cleric's Sons Arrested The two sons of a prominent dissident cleric, Grand Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri, were arrested in Iran after defying a ban on the use of an office in the city of Qum.

Saudis Say a Plot Is Thwarted Saudi Arabia said the police had foiled an imminent terrorist attack and killed two militants in a shootout in Mecca, seizing rocket-propelled grenades, rifles, pistols, explosives, ammunition and passports.
Yukos Oil President Resigns Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, imprisoned since Oct. 25 on charges of embezzlement, fraud and tax evasion, resigned as chairman of Yukos Oil, Russia's richest company.

Miasma in a Chinese Town Hisun, one of China's leading exporters of pharmaceutical products, may pay more attention to fighting cancer in America than to protecting the health of its workers and neighbors in Taizhou, a city whose air and water are being polluted by Hisun's poisonous waste.

Presidential Candidates Tackle Issues and Reality President Bush and Howard Dean, at separate appearances, offered a snapshot of the presidential contest, as realities on the ground -- upbeat economic growth figures and a deadly helicopter attack in Iraq -- intruded on the candidates' plans.

New Phase in Sniper Trial Prosecutors closed the first phase of their case against John A. Muhammad, who is accused of masterminding last fall's sniper shootings, with the testimony of Whitney Donahue, whose call to the police led to Mr. Muhammad's arrest.
Graham to Leave the Senate Senator Bob Graham, a moderate Democrat from Florida, announced that he would not seek a fourth term, adding a new hurdle for Democrats in the Senate.

Cost Controls for Medicare The Bush administration joined House Republicans in pushing a proposal that would force Congress to vote on possible cutbacks in Medicare if the costs of the program, including new drug benefits, grow faster than expected.
Young Surfer Victim of Shark Bethany Hamilton, 13, one of the country's top female amateur surfers, was in stable condition after being attacked by a shark in Kauai.
Anglican Divide Widens Africa's Anglican leaders expressed fury at the consecration of a gay bishop in New Hampshire, saying that they will not recognize the action.

Outcry on Editing of Report Two leading House Democrats asked the Justice Department's inspector general to investigate the department's decision to delete large parts of a report on employee diversity before releasing it publicly.

Mayor Proposes School Aid Mayor Bloomberg proposed $13.1 billion in school construction and repairs over five years -- the most ambitious education capital plan in city history -- and demanded that Albany foot at least half of the bill.

Lawyers Seek Clients Among Ferry Passengers Lawyers have recruited as clients some of the passengers who were on the Staten Island ferry that crashed last month, to the dismay of some legal organizations. About 40 survivors have signaled that they intend to sue the city.
Hospital Finances at a Low Hospitals in New York State are the nation's weakest financially, according to a national analysis.

Defending Abuse Charges The allies of the New Jersey couple charged with starving their adopted sons are mounting an increasingly orchestrated defense effort, and the facts of the case have become the subject of a war of words, faxes, Web sites and spin in an attempt to shape public opinion.

CBS Weighs Canceling Series CBS, under pressure from Republicans and conservative groups, is weighing a decision to scrap a completed four-hour mini-series, ''The Reagans,'' an unflattering portrait of former President Ronald Reagan and his wife, Nancy, according to a person involved in the production.

Energy an Issue With Warming There is no consensus in how to meet the challenge of a top-to-bottom revamping of the world's energy systems that would be needed if predictions about global warming were proven correct.
Pediatricians and Obesity The surgeon general urged pediatricians to do more to combat childhood obesity.

Hard Times for Mutual Funds The mutual fund industry was further battered by details of widespread trading abuses and the disclosure by federal regulators that the industry faced an imminent wave of government lawsuits.
Putnam Chief Steps Down The chief executive of Putnam Investments resigned less than a week after securities regulators sued the company for fraud.

Scrushy Indictment Near The Justice Department is expected to announce the indictment of Richard M. Scrushy, the ousted chief executive and founder of HealthSouth, on charges connected to six years of reports of inflated profits.
Cotton Subsidy Draws Fire Foreign cotton growers are increasingly critical of a federal farm subsidy program.
Editorials: The post-Grasso exchange; difficult days in Iraq; choices for Election Day; Andrew Johnston on the public face of a private artist.
